fields.descriptive_line: Guardi, Francesco (1712-1793).  Design for a bisona, with two  gondoliers in Chinese dress.  Watercolour.

fields.name: Francesco Guardi 1712-1793: Commemorating the third Centenary of the artist's birth

fields.physical_description: Design in watercolour for a Bissona. The two gondoliers on the right of the composition are shown in Chinese dress.

fields.title: Design for a bissona, with two gondoliers in Chinese dress
fields.materials_techniques: pen, ink and watercolour over traces of pencil

fields.exhibition_history:
Francesco Guardi 1712-1793: Commemorating the third Centenary of the artist's birth (Museo Correr, Venice 28 Sept 2012-7 Jan 2013)
Venetian Visions (Victoria and Albert Museum, Galleries 88a and 90 07/10/11-01/04/12)
fields.bibliography: Morassi, Antonio. Guardi, tutti is disegni di Antonio, Francesco e Giacomo Guardi, (Venice: Alfieri, 1975), p.131, cat. 304, plate.305. Ward-Jackson, Peter. Italian Drawings: volume Two 17th-18th century, (London: Her Majesty's Stationery Office, 1980), catalogue 1033, p.150. The following is the full text of the entry: GUARDI, FRANCESCO (1712-93) 1033 Design for a bissona, with two gondoliers in Chinese dress Pen and ink and water-colour over black chalk 13 5/8 x 21 5/8 (339 x 550) 144 PROVENANCE Bought 1857 LITERATURE J. Byam Shaw in OMD (references as in no. 1032), pl. 20; the same, The Drawings of Francesco Guardi, p. 73; Exhibition Catalogue Drawings by Old Masters (as in no. 1032), no. 183; Parker and Byam Shaw, no. 84; Morassi, Tutti I disegni, no. 304, pl. 305 The bissona was a richly decorated craft used by the great Venetian families at regattas etc. Other designs by Guardi and others are illustrated in G. Lorenzetti, Le Feste e le maschere veneziane, Venice, 1937, together with contemporary paintings showing the craft in use. There is no proof that our two drawings of a bissona are working designs rather than studies for pictures, but the large scale and the fact that the drawings exactly fill the sheets suggest this conclusion. A similar drawing of about the same size in the Correr Museum at Venice has a scale of measurement below, which supports the supposition. But Morassi lists and illustrates several paintings in which Guardi seems to have used our two studies or designs. Byam Shaw, J.J. 'Four drawings by Francesco Guardi in English Public Collections', in Old Master Drawings, XII, 1937, pp.18-21, fig.20. Drawings by the Old Masters, exhibition catalogue, (London: Royal Academy, 1953), p.48, n.183. Byam Shaw, J.J. 'A sketch for a ceiling by Francesco Guardi', in The Burlington Magazine, February 1962, CIV, p. 64, mp. 84. Alberto Craievich, Filippo Pedrocco, Francesco Guardi 1712-1793 Venice, 2012. ISBN: 978-88-572-1481-8
fields.history_note: Historical significance: Francesco Guardi was the most celebrated member of a family of eighteenth-century Venetian artists. After the death of his brother Giovanni in the middle of the century, Francesco established himself as a Veduta painter. Although he borrowed from many artists, the most important source of inspiration in his early period was certainly Canaletto. However, the painters probably had never worked together. Guardi followed closely Canaletto’s drawings and engravings in his topographically accurate views of Venice, which were in demand among foreign collectors. Later in the 1770s and 1780s, Guardi’s style becomes looser and freer. He also painted the figures according to contemporary fashion, which makes his paintings a valuable indication of the current trends in hairstyle and dress. The ladies in his works from that period wear high coiffures decorated with feathers and flowers inspired by French and English fashions. Guardi was more comfortable with small figures in architectural setting than with large-scale religious scenes in altarpieces. Venetian patrons preferred Guardi’s imaginary views, called capricci, to the straightforward recreations of the architecture of the city. The motifs include creative ensembles of classical architecture, picturesque ruins, Gothic arches, harbours and obelisks. Guardi often repeated these details introducing slight variations. Identifiable architectural details from Venice, such as the Doge’s Palace, conflate in the capricci with fruits of Guardi’s imagination. Francesco Guardi died in 1793. As a major figure on the artistic scene, his characteristic style and considerable output encouraged many forgeries, especially in the medium of drawing. This drawing depicts a bissona, or a ceremonial, richly decorated gondola used by Venetian families in regattas. Uniquely among such designs by Guardi, this one contains two figures of gondoliers, both in Chinese costume. The scale of the drawing and the fact that the bissona occupies the entire sheet suggests that it might have been a working design serving as basis for construction. However, it lacks measurements and technical discipline. The design seems to have been used in Guardi’s painting practice. A similar bissona, although reduced in scale and shown from different angles, occurs in Guardi’s paintings depicting the lavish regatta on the Venetian canals (Morassi, 1973, II, (cat. 331, 33) Guardi might have used the splendour of Venetian regattas as a source of inspiration to transform the architectural construction into a decorative fantasy. The colours are rich and carefully worked out, convincingly evoking the splendid decoration of the bissona. The sheet has trace of vertical folding in the middle. A design for another bissona, similar in scale and style, is catalogued under 143. Similar depictions of decorative bissone are in the Ashmolean Museum and the Museo Correr (inv. 7314, 61). References: Morassi, Antonio; Guardi: Antonio e Francesco Guardi, (Alfieri, Venice 1973)
